properties.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 2 at 3:22PM EST by NWS Tallahassee FL
properties.description:
.Summary...
A multi-day rainfall event is expected across the region starting
Tuesday and continuing into Thursday. This series of storm systems
will bring periods of moderate to heavy rain over an area that has
already experienced above normal rainfall through the winter months.
With many area rivers already running above normal, additional river
flooding is expected in the days ahead.

.Flood Potential and Concerns...
While rainfall across the southern portion of our region has been
near to below normal over the last couple of months, rainfall
further north, mainly along and north of a line from Dothan to
Albany has been much above normal. With the bulk of the heavy rain
expected across the northern half of our region, this sets the stage
for additional river flooding and some flash flooding.

There still is a little uncertainty with the track and timing of the
approaching storm system, however the general consensus is that much
of the area in Southeast Alabama and Southwestern Georgia could see
2 to 4 inches of rain with isolated heavier totals near 6 inches.
Lighter totals are anticipated further south into the Florida
Panhandle and Big Bend.

Based on the latest rainfall forecast and current river conditions,
these rivers or creeks have the greatest potential to see additional
river flooding:

1) Apalachicola River
2) Chattahoochee River
3) Flint River
4) Kinchafoonee Creek
5) Muckalee Creek
6) Choctawhatchee River
7) Pea River (at Ariton)
8) Ochlockonee River (in Florida)

Increased releases from upstream on the Chattahoochee could also
further increase the flood potential on the Chattahoochee and
Apalachicola Rivers into the weekend.

Flash flooding is also a concern, but the risk for flash flooding
will occur on Wednesday and Thursday, mainly across Southeastern
Alabama and Southwestern Georgia. Rainfall rates in Florida are not
anticipated to be high enough to support flash flooding in this
event.

.Preparedness Actions...
Should the forecast continue to indicate an increased risk of
flooding across the area later this week, a flood watch may be
issued for a portion of our area on Tuesday.

Residents living along area creeks and rivers should consider
evaluating their flood threat, especially in locations with
already above normal river levels.

For an assessment of current and future hydrologic information in
the Tallahassee area of responsibility, visit our website at
www.weather.gov/tallahassee and click on the rivers and lakes
link.

Users of our hydrologic forecasts are reminded that these
predictions only utilize the next 48 hours of rainfall, so river
forecasts issued Tuesday morning will begin to include rainfall from
most of this upcoming event. You can also follow and interact with
our office through Twitter @NWSTallahassee.

NWSheadline: POTENTIAL FOR RIVER FLOODING INCREASING THIS WEEK AND INTO THE WEEKEND... ...FLASH FLOODING POSSIBLE WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY
